result.markdown:
# String






## Create String

Enclose your String in " " or """ """!


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
s1 = "I am a string."
#> "I am a string."
typeof(s1)
#> String
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
s2 = """I am also a string. """
#> "I am also a string. "
typeof(s2)
#> String
```
:::


Single quote is for `Char`


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
typeof('a')
#> Char
```
:::


## String Interpolation

Similar to shell


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
name = "Joe"
num_fingers = 10
num_toes = 10
```
:::


Use `$` to refer to variable.


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
println("Hello, my name is $name.")
#> Hello, my name is Joe.
println("I have $num_fingers fingers and $num_toes toes.")
#> I have 10 fingers and 10 toes.
```
:::


Run expression in `$(command)`


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
println("That is $(num_fingers + num_toes) digits in all!!")
#> That is 20 digits in all!!
```
:::


## Concatenate String


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
s3 = "How many cats ";
s4 = "is too many cats?";
ðŸ˜º = 10
```
:::


`string()` converts non-string inputs to strings.


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
string(s3, s4)
#> "How many cats is too many cats?"
```
:::


We can also use `*` for concatenation!


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
s3 * s4
#> "How many cats is too many cats?"
```
:::



## Exercise

Create a string that says "hi" 3 times, first with repeat and then with the exponentiation operator, which can call * under the hood. Assign it the variable hi below.


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
repeat("hi", 3)
#> "hihihi"
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
"hi"^3
#> "hihihi"
```
:::



Declare two variables



::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
a = 3
b = 4
```
:::


and use them to create two strings:


::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
c = string(a) * " + " * string(b)
#> "3 + 4"
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.julia .cell-code}
d = string(a + b)
#> "7"
```
:::
